tenses.description: Used to describe actions happening now, general truths, or habitual actions. In Russian, the present tense of 'быть' is rarely used in modern language, replaced by the absence of a verb.
Used to describe completed actions in the past. Russian past tense is formed by adding gender endings to the verb stem and doesn't require auxiliary verbs.
Used to express future actions, predictions, or intentions. Russian future tense is formed using the auxiliary verb 'быть' (to be) in its future form plus the infinitive.
Used to give commands, orders, or instructions. Russian imperative has different forms for singular and plural, and the subject pronoun is usually omitted.
Used to express hypothetical situations, wishes, or actions that would happen under certain conditions. Formed by adding 'бы' to the past tense form.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Я был бы счастлив, если бы ты пришёл
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I would be happy if you came
You would be a good teacher

conjugations.exampleSentence: Он был бы рад помочь тебе, если бы знал
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: He would be glad to help you if he knew

conjugations.exampleSentence: Она была бы здесь, если бы не опоздала на поезд
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: She would be here if she hadn't missed the train

conjugations.exampleSentence: Мы были бы там раньше, если бы не пробки
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: We would have been there earlier if not for the traffic

conjugations.exampleSentence: Вы были бы удивлены, увидев эти изменения
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: You would be surprised to see these changes

conjugations.exampleSentence: Они были бы лучшими друзьями, если бы лучше понимали друг друга
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: They would be best friends if they understood each other better

tenses.description: The verb 'быть' does not have a present gerund form in modern Russian, as it lacks a present tense conjugation in standard usage.
Used to express an action that occurred simultaneously with or before the main action. Functions as an adverb and is invariable.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: Being a student, he worked a lot

conjugations.exampleSentence: Бывши за границей, она узнала много нового
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: Having been abroad, she learned many new things

tenses.description: The verb 'быть' does not have a present active participle in modern Russian.
Used to describe a noun that performed an action in the past. Functions as an adjective and agrees with the noun in gender, number, and case.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: The former president gave a speech
The former teacher visited the school
Former colleagues met at the conference

tenses.description: The verb 'быть' does not form a present passive participle.
The verb 'быть' does not form a past passive participle as it is intransitive.
Used to describe actions happening now, general truths, or habitual actions. This is the most commonly used tense in Russian.
Used to describe completed actions in the past. Russian past tense is formed by adding gender endings to the verb stem and doesn't require auxiliary verbs.
Used to express future actions, predictions, or intentions. Russian future tense is formed using the auxiliary verb 'быть' (to be) in its future form plus the infinitive.
Used to give commands, orders, or instructions. Russian imperative has different forms for singular and plural, and the subject pronoun is usually omitted.
Used to express hypothetical situations, wishes, or actions that would happen under certain conditions. Formed by adding 'бы' to the past tense form.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Я имел бы больше времени, если бы начал раньше
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I would have more time if I had started earlier

conjugations.exampleSentence: Ты имел бы больше друзей, если бы был более открытым
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: You would have more friends if you were more open

conjugations.exampleSentence: Он имел бы успех, если бы упорно работал
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: He would have success if he worked hard

conjugations.exampleSentence: Она имела бы лучшую жизнь, если бы сделала другой выбор
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: She would have a better life if she had made a different choice

conjugations.exampleSentence: Мы имели бы меньше проблем, если бы были лучше подготовлены
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: We would have fewer problems if we were better prepared

conjugations.exampleSentence: Вы имели бы возможность встретить его, если бы пришли
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: You would have had the opportunity to meet him if you had come

conjugations.exampleSentence: Они имели бы больше успеха с другой стратегией
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: They would have more success with a different strategy

tenses.description: Used to express an action occurring simultaneously with the main action. Functions as an adverb and is invariable.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Имея большой опыт, он легко решил проблему
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: Having great experience, he easily solved the problem

conjugations.exampleSentence: Имея свободное время, она читает книги
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: Having free time, she reads books

tenses.description: Used to express an action that occurred before the main action. Functions as an adverb and is invariable.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Имев возможность учиться, он стал врачом
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: Having had the opportunity to study, he became a doctor

conjugations.exampleSentence: Имевши большие планы, они начали новый проект
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: Having had big plans, they started a new project

tenses.description: Used to describe a noun that is currently performing an action. Functions as an adjective and agrees with the noun in gender, number, and case.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Человек, имеющий власть, должен быть ответственным
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: A person having power must be responsible
The company having experience got the contract
The proposal having sense was accepted

conjugations.exampleSentence: Студенты, имеющие вопросы, могут задать их
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: Students having questions can ask them

tenses.description: Used to describe a noun that performed an action in the past. Functions as an adjective and agrees with the noun in gender, number, and case.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Человек, имевший влияние, ушёл на пенсию
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: The person who had influence retired

conjugations.exampleSentence: Семья, имевшая традиции, переехала в город
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: The family that had traditions moved to the city
The state that had colonies collapsed
People who had hope continued to fight

tenses.description: The verb 'иметь' does not form a present passive participle in standard Russian usage.
Used to describe a noun that was the object of an action in the past. Functions as an adjective and agrees with the noun in gender, number, and case. Rare for 'иметь'.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: The success had by the team is impressive
The goal had by everyone unites people
The right had by citizens is protected by law
The opportunities had by youth are limitless

tenses.description: Used to describe actions happening now, general truths, or habitual actions. This is the most commonly used tense in Russian.
Used to describe completed actions in the past. The form changes based on gender and number.
Used to express future actions, predictions, or intentions. Often used with time expressions like 'завтра' (tomorrow).

conjugations.exampleSentence: Я буду идти в школу завтра
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I will go to school tomorrow
He will go to the cinema
We will go for a walk
They will go to the theater

tenses.description: Used to give commands, orders, or instructions. Only exists for the second person (ты, вы).
Used to express hypothetical situations or actions that would happen under certain conditions. Often used with 'если' (if) clauses.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Я шёл бы в школу, если бы имел время
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I would go to school if I had time
He would go to the cinema
We would go for a walk
They would go to the theater

tenses.description: Used as an adjective to describe someone who is currently performing the action. Must agree in gender, number, and case.
Used as an adjective to describe someone who performed the action in the past. Must agree in gender, number, and case.
Used as an adjective to describe something that is currently being acted upon. Must agree in gender, number, and case.
Used as an adjective to describe something that was acted upon in the past. Must agree in gender, number, and case.
Used to express an action that happens simultaneously with the main action. Often used to show manner or condition.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: While going to school, I think
While going to the cinema, we talked

tenses.description: Used to express an action that was completed before the main action. Often used to show sequence of events.
Used to describe actions happening now, general truths, or habitual actions. This is the most commonly used tense in Russian.
Used to describe completed actions in the past. The form changes based on gender and number.
Used to express future actions, predictions, or intentions. Often used with time expressions like 'завтра' (tomorrow).

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I will do my homework tomorrow

tenses.description: Used to give commands, orders, or instructions. Only exists for the second person (ты, вы).
Used to express hypothetical situations or actions that would happen under certain conditions. Often used with 'если' (if) clauses.

conjugations.exampleSentence: Я делал бы уроки, если бы имел время
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I would do my homework if I had time

tenses.description: Used as an adjective to describe someone who is currently performing the action. Must agree in gender, number, and case.
Used as an adjective to describe someone who performed the action in the past. Must agree in gender, number, and case.
Used as an adjective to describe something that is currently being acted upon. Must agree in gender, number, and case.
Used as an adjective to describe something that was acted upon in the past. Must agree in gender, number, and case.
Used to express an action that happens simultaneously with the main action. Often used to show manner or condition.
Used to express an action that was completed before the main action. Often used to show sequence of events.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: Having done homework, I went for a walk
Having done shopping, he went home

conjugations.exampleSentence: Сделав кофе, мы сели за стол
conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: Having made coffee, we sat at the table

tenses.description: Used to describe actions happening now, general truths, or habitual actions. This is the most commonly used tense in Russian.
Used to describe completed actions in the past. The form changes based on gender and number.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: I will be able to help tomorrow

Used to express an action that happens simultaneously with the main action. Often used to show manner or condition.

conjugations.exampleSentenceEn: While being able to help, I think
